*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: draft.md
+# One global voice layer for Microsoft Teams Phone
+
+If you run Microsoft Teams Phone across multiple countries, you quickly learn that the hardest part is not the user experience. It is everything wrapped around the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN), the local numbers, the contracts, the compliance and the operational effort needed to keep it all working.
+
+For years, global telephony meant building a patchwork. A local PBX here, a carrier contract there, and a growing list of country exceptions that lived in spreadsheets and inboxes. Even when organisations moved away from on premises kit, the fragmentation often stayed. The calling platform could be global, but the voice layer still looked like a map of local decisions.
+
+That fragmentation creates real costs that do not show up in the headline carrier rate.
+
+- Procurement never stops, different terms, pricing models, renewal dates and legal positions by country
+- Governance gets messy, inconsistent numbering plans, emergency calling practices and change controls
+- Operations slows down, every move, add or change becomes a coordination exercise across suppliers
+- Service quality is harder to manage, no single owner for end to end performance or incident response
+
+This is the gap LoopUp is designed to close.
+
+LoopUp provides cloud telephony for Microsoft Teams Phone with a single telco provider model, so you are not stitching together multiple carriers to make Teams work globally. In practice, that means LoopUp can deliver PSTN connectivity to Teams users across geographies under one commercial relationship, with one operational model.
+
+Organisations typically connect LoopUp to Microsoft Teams Phone via Operator Connect or Direct Routing, depending on their architecture preferences and where they want responsibility to sit. Either way, the goal is the same. Reduce the number of moving parts between Teams and the PSTN and make ownership clear.
+
+The value is not abstract. It shows up in day to day execution.
+
+First, you simplify delivery. Rolling out Teams Phone to a new country stops being a separate sourcing project. You get a repeatable pattern for numbers, porting, activation and lifecycle management.
+
+Second, you make change safer. When there is one provider accountable for the voice layer, troubleshooting is faster and post incident learning is actionable. You can also standardise policy across sites, including how you handle numbering, routing and emergency calling.
+
+Third, you regain commercial control. One supplier means fewer renewal cliffs, fewer hidden cost categories and less internal time spent reconciling invoices. It also makes it easier to forecast spend when you are scaling or restructuring.
+
+Finally, you set yourself up for long term simplification. A global Teams Phone strategy only really becomes an operating model when it is supported by a global approach to PSTN connectivity, not a collection of local exceptions.
+
+Most enterprises do not need more telephony features. They need fewer suppliers, fewer surprises and a voice layer that behaves like the rest of their cloud estate. That is what a mature, single provider approach can deliver.
*** End Patch

# One global voice layer for Microsoft Teams Phone

If you run Microsoft Teams Phone across multiple countries, you quickly learn that the hardest part is not the user experience. It is everything wrapped around the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN), the local numbers, the contracts, the compliance and the operational effort needed to keep it all working.

For years, global telephony meant building a patchwork. A local PBX here, a carrier contract there, and a growing list of country exceptions that lived in spreadsheets and inboxes. Even when organisations moved away from on premises kit, the fragmentation often stayed. The calling platform could be global, but the voice layer still looked like a map of local decisions.

That fragmentation creates real costs that do not show up in the headline carrier rate.

- Procurement never stops, different terms, pricing models, renewal dates and legal positions by country
- Governance gets messy, inconsistent numbering plans, emergency calling practices and change controls
- Operations slows down, every move, add or change becomes a coordination exercise across suppliers
- Service quality is harder to manage, no single owner for end to end performance or incident response

This is the gap LoopUp is designed to close.

LoopUp provides cloud telephony for Microsoft Teams Phone with a single telco provider model, so you are not stitching together multiple carriers to make Teams work globally. In practice, that means LoopUp can deliver PSTN connectivity to Teams users across geographies under one commercial relationship, with one operational model.

Organisations typically connect LoopUp to Microsoft Teams Phone via Operator Connect or Direct Routing, depending on their architecture preferences and where they want responsibility to sit. Either way, the goal is the same. Reduce the number of moving parts between Teams and the PSTN and make ownership clear.

The value is not abstract. It shows up in day to day execution.

First, you simplify delivery. Rolling out Teams Phone to a new country stops being a separate sourcing project. You get a repeatable pattern for numbers, porting, activation and lifecycle management.

Second, you make change safer. When there is one provider accountable for the voice layer, troubleshooting is faster and post incident learning is actionable. You can also standardise policy across sites, including how you handle numbering, routing and emergency calling.

Third, you regain commercial control. One supplier means fewer renewal cliffs, fewer hidden cost categories and less internal time spent reconciling invoices. It also makes it easier to forecast spend when you are scaling or restructuring.

Finally, you set yourself up for long term simplification. A global Teams Phone strategy only really becomes an operating model when it is supported by a global approach to PSTN connectivity, not a collection of local exceptions.

Most enterprises do not need more telephony features. They need fewer suppliers, fewer surprises and a voice layer that behaves like the rest of their cloud estate. That is what a mature, single provider approach can deliver.

# One global voice layer for Microsoft Teams Phone

If you run Microsoft Teams Phone across multiple countries, you quickly learn that the hardest part is not the user experience. It is everything wrapped around the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN), the local numbers, the contracts, the compliance and the operational effort needed to keep it all working.

For years, global telephony meant building a patchwork. A local PBX here, a carrier contract there, and a growing list of country exceptions that lived in spreadsheets and inboxes. Even when organisations moved away from on premises kit, the fragmentation often stayed. The calling platform could be global, but the voice layer still looked like a map of local decisions.

That fragmentation creates real costs that do not show up in the headline carrier rate.

- Procurement never stops, different terms, pricing models, renewal dates and legal positions by country
- Governance gets messy, inconsistent numbering plans, emergency calling practices and change controls
- Operations slows down, every move, add or change becomes a coordination exercise across suppliers
- Service quality is harder to manage, no single owner for end to end performance or incident response

This is the gap LoopUp is designed to close.

LoopUp provides cloud telephony for Microsoft Teams Phone with a single telco provider model, so you are not stitching together multiple carriers to make Teams work globally. In practice, that means LoopUp can deliver PSTN connectivity to Teams users across geographies under one commercial relationship, with one operational model.

Organisations typically connect LoopUp to Microsoft Teams Phone via Operator Connect or Direct Routing, depending on their architecture preferences and where they want responsibility to sit. Either way, the goal is the same. Reduce the number of moving parts between Teams and the PSTN and make ownership clear.

The value is not abstract. It shows up in day to day execution.

First, you simplify delivery. Rolling out Teams Phone to a new country stops being a separate sourcing project. You get a repeatable pattern for numbers, porting, activation and lifecycle management.

Second, you make change safer. When there is one provider accountable for the voice layer, troubleshooting is faster and post incident learning is actionable. You can also standardise policy across sites, including how you handle numbering, routing and emergency calling.

Third, you regain commercial control. One supplier means fewer renewal cliffs, fewer hidden cost categories and less internal time spent reconciling invoices. It also makes it easier to forecast spend when you are scaling or restructuring.

Finally, you set yourself up for long term simplification. A global Teams Phone strategy only really becomes an operating model when it is supported by a global approach to PSTN connectivity, not a collection of local exceptions.

Most enterprises do not need more telephony features. They need fewer suppliers, fewer surprises and a voice layer that behaves like the rest of their cloud estate. That is what a mature, single provider approach can deliver.

# New Test

**Type**: blog

## Brief

Celebrate the achievements of our very own Zach Bennett, Teams MVP.

Emphasis: a balanced mix of community contribution, customer impact, and the work Zach does with the LoopUp team.

messages.content: Celebrate the achievements of our very own Zach Bennett, Teams MVP.

questions.question: Which 3 to 5 specific achievements should the post highlight about Zach Bennett as a Microsoft Teams MVP, for example community contributions, speaking, customer impact, internal work at LoopUp, and should we include any links or quotes?

options.label: Share a short bullet list
options.description: You provide 3 to 5 achievements plus any links or quotes, I write from that.

options.label: Focus on community and speaking
options.description: I emphasise public contributions, events, and thought leadership, light on internal details.

options.label: Focus on customer impact
options.description: I emphasise programmes, deployments, outcomes, and lessons learned, with careful detail.

options.label: Balanced mix
options.description: I cover community, customer impact, and LoopUp teamwork evenly.

parts.text:
[analyze-mode]
ANALYSIS MODE. Gather context before diving deep:

CONTEXT GATHERING (parallel):
- 1-2 explore agents (codebase patterns, implementations)
- 1-2 librarian agents (if external library involved)
- Direct tools: Grep, AST-grep, LSP for targeted searches

IF COMPLEX - DO NOT STRUGGLE ALONE. Consult specialists:
- **Oracle**: Conventional problems (architecture, debugging, complex logic)
- **Artistry**: Non-conventional problems (different approach needed)

SYNTHESIZE findings before proceeding.

---

**LoopUp Content Generator**

The text following these instructions is the content brief. Analyse and clarify
with the user before generating final output.

=============================================================================
HARD RULES (check output against these before delivering)
=============================================================================

1. NO em-dashes (—). Use commas, full stops, or restructure instead.

2. NO colon-split headings. Never write "Topic: Subtitle" format.
   BAD: "The Challenge: Why Enterprises Struggle"
   GOOD: "Why enterprises struggle with carrier fragmentation"

3. NO semicolon overuse. Maximum one per article.

4. NO filler phrases: "In today's world", "It's important to note",
   "What this means is", "At the end of the day".

5. NO buzzwords: "unlock", "leverage", "holistic", "cutting-edge",
   "game-changing", "best-in-class", "seamless", "delve", "landscape".

6. NO one-shot responses. Always clarify format and brief first.

7. BRIEF FILE ONLY: The content brief must live in brief.md in the project folder.
   Create or update brief.md whenever the brief changes.

8. DRAFT FILE ONLY: The marketing output must live in draft.md in the project
   folder. Create or update draft.md for all content output and edits.

9. NO OTHER FILES: Never create any other files. Do not create outline.md or

projects.name: Activity Test
projects.brief: Write a short blog post about the benefits of remote work for technology companies. Focus on productivity gains and talent acquisition.
projects.documentContent:
# Remote work that actually helps tech companies

Remote work is often framed as a perk. In most technology companies, it is closer to an operating model choice. Done well, it can improve how work gets done and widen the pool of people you can hire. Done poorly, it can create delays, misalignment, and a slow drift in culture.

This is not about ideology. It is about results. Two outcomes tend to matter most for tech leaders making the decision at scale, productivity and talent.

## Productivity goes up when focus goes up

Many engineering and product teams do their best work in long, uninterrupted stretches. For some people, the office helps. For many, it does not. Remote work gives individuals more control over their focus time and the rhythm of their day. Fewer ad hoc interruptions, less time spent commuting, and more ability to structure deep work hours can translate into real output.

The productivity gain is not automatic. It comes from being deliberate about how work moves.

- Write things down. Decisions, context, and requirements live in shared docs, not in someone else's memory.
- Default to asynchronous updates. Not every question needs a meeting.
- Use meetings for what they are good at. Unblocking, debate, and alignment, not status reporting.
- Measure outcomes. Cycle time, incident rates, and customer impact tell you more than activity.

When teams adopt these habits, remote work tends to push clarity. If you cannot explain a decision clearly in writing, it probably is not clear yet. That is a helpful pressure.

## Talent acquisition becomes a strategic advantage

The best person for a role does not always live within commuting distance of your HQ. Remote work lets you recruit across geographies, which matters for hard-to-fill roles like senior engineers, security specialists, and experienced product managers.

It also helps with retention. People who have built a life around family, caregiving, or a particular location are less likely to churn when they do not have to choose between career growth and stability at home.

For global companies, remote work can also improve coverage. You can build teams that span time zones intentionally, using follow-the-sun handoffs for support and operations. That can reduce after-hours load and improve response times, as long as ownership and escalation paths stay clear.

## The trade-offs are real, but manageable

Remote work can fail in predictable ways. Onboarding can feel slower. New hires miss the informal context that used to come from overhearing conversations. Collaboration can become noisy if every interaction turns into a chat thread.

The fix is not to pull everyone back into the office. It is to design for remote.

- Invest in onboarding. A written first-week plan, a buddy system, and a clear map of who owns what.
- Protect time for connection. Regular team rituals that are not performative.
- Make hybrid fair. If some people are in a room, make the meeting remote-first so nobody is a second-class participant.

## A pragmatic way to think about it

Remote work is a multiplier. Strong teams with clear goals and good habits often get better. Teams with fuzzy ownership and weak communication often feel the cracks faster.

If you treat remote work as an operating model, not a perk, it can improve productivity and open up access to talent you would otherwise never reach. For many technology companies, that combination is hard to ignore.

Remote work gives individuals more control over their focus time and the rhythm of their day. Fewer ad hoc interruptions, less time spent commuting, and more ability to structure deep work hours can translate into real output.
+
+The productivity gain is not automatic. It comes from being deliberate about how work moves.
+
+- Write things down. Decisions, context, and requirements live in shared docs, not in someone else's memory.
+- Default to asynchronous updates. Not every question needs a meeting.
+- Use meetings for what they are good at. Unblocking, debate, and alignment, not status reporting.
+- Measure outcomes. Cycle time, incident rates, and customer impact tell you more than activity.
+
+When teams adopt these habits, remote work tends to push clarity. If you cannot explain a decision clearly in writing, it probably is not clear yet. That is a helpful pressure.
+
+## Talent acquisition becomes a strategic advantage
+
+The best person for a role does not always live within commuting distance of your HQ. Remote work lets you recruit across geographies, which matters for hard-to-fill roles like senior engineers, security specialists, and experienced product managers.
+
+It also helps with retention. People who have built a life around family, caregiving, or a particular location are less likely to churn when they do not have to choose between career growth and stability at home.
+
+For global companies, remote work can also improve coverage. You can build teams that span time zones intentionally, using follow-the-sun handoffs for support and operations. That can reduce after-hours load and improve response times, as long as ownership and escalation paths stay clear.
+
+## The trade-offs are real, but manageable
+
+Remote work can fail in predictable ways. Onboarding can feel slower. New hires miss the informal context that used to come from overhearing conversations. Collaboration can become noisy if every interaction turns into a chat thread.
+
+The fix is not to pull everyone back into the office. It is to design for remote.
+
+- Invest in onboarding. A written first-week plan, a buddy system, and a clear map of who owns what.
+- Protect time for connection. Regular team rituals that are not performative.
+- Make hybrid fair. If some people are in a room, make the meeting remote-first so nobody is a second-class participant.
+
+## A pragmatic way to think about it
+
+Remote work is a multiplier. Strong teams with clear goals and good habits often get better. Teams with fuzzy ownership and weak communication often feel the cracks faster.
+
+If you treat remote work as an operating model, not a perk, it can improve productivity and open up access to talent you would otherwise never reach. For many technology companies, that combination is hard to ignore.

# Remote work that actually helps tech companies

Remote work is often framed as a perk. In most technology companies, it is closer to an operating model choice. Done well, it can improve how work gets done and widen the pool of people you can hire. Done poorly, it can create delays, misalignment, and a slow drift in culture.

This is not about ideology. It is about results. Two outcomes tend to matter most for tech leaders making the decision at scale, productivity and talent.

## Productivity goes up when focus goes up

Many engineering and product teams do their best work in long, uninterrupted stretches. For some people, the office helps. For many, it does not. Remote work gives individuals more control over their focus time and the rhythm of their day. Fewer ad hoc interruptions, less time spent commuting, and more ability to structure deep work hours can translate into real output.

The productivity gain is not automatic. It comes from being deliberate about how work moves.

- Write things down. Decisions, context, and requirements live in shared docs, not in someone else's memory.
- Default to asynchronous updates. Not every question needs a meeting.
- Use meetings for what they are good at. Unblocking, debate, and alignment, not status reporting.
- Measure outcomes. Cycle time, incident rates, and customer impact tell you more than activity.

When teams adopt these habits, remote work tends to push clarity. If you cannot explain a decision clearly in writing, it probably is not clear yet. That is a helpful pressure.

## Talent acquisition becomes a strategic advantage

The best person for a role does not always live within commuting distance of your HQ. Remote work lets you recruit across geographies, which matters for hard-to-fill roles like senior engineers, security specialists, and experienced product managers.

It also helps with retention. People who have built a life around family, caregiving, or a particular location are less likely to churn when they do not have to choose between career growth and stability at home.

For global companies, remote work can also improve coverage. You can build teams that span time zones intentionally, using follow-the-sun handoffs for support and operations. That can reduce after-hours load and improve response times, as long as ownership and escalation paths stay clear.

## The trade-offs are real, but manageable

Remote work can fail in predictable ways. Onboarding can feel slower. New hires miss the informal context that used to come from overhearing conversations. Collaboration can become noisy if every interaction turns into a chat thread.

The fix is not to pull everyone back into the office. It is to design for remote.

- Invest in onboarding. A written first-week plan, a buddy system, and a clear map of who owns what.
- Protect time for connection. Regular team rituals that are not performative.
- Make hybrid fair. If some people are in a room, make the meeting remote-first so nobody is a second-class participant.

## A pragmatic way to think about it

Remote work is a multiplier. Strong teams with clear goals and good habits often get better. Teams with fuzzy ownership and weak communication often feel the cracks faster.

If you treat remote work as an operating model, not a perk, it can improve productivity and open up access to talent you would otherwise never reach. For many technology companies, that combination is hard to ignore.
